instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used on the quantitative description of the degree of nitrogen (N) deficiency in rice?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used on the quantitative description of the degree of nitrogen (N) deficiency in rice were the ratio spectrum reflectivity (RSV) and difference spectrum reflectivity (RD).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy on the quantitative description of the degree of nitrogen (N) deficiency in rice, and how well did this metric perform?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the inversion models constructed in the study was the coefficient of determination (R2) and the root mean square error (RMSE). 

The R2 values of the training set and validation set for the inversion results based on the ratio spectrum and NSGA-III-ELM algorithm were 0.852 and 0.810, respectively. This indicates that the inversion model was able to explain 85.2% and 81.0% of the variance in the N deficiency data in the training and validation sets, respectively.

The RMSE values for the training set and validation set were 0.291 and 0.308, respectively. The RMSE measures the average difference between the predicted N deficiency values and the actual N deficiency values. Lower RMSE values indicate better accuracy. In this case, the RMSE values suggest that the inversion model had an average difference of 0.291 and 0.308 between the predicted and actual N deficiency values in the training and validation sets, respectively.

Overall, the chosen metrics of R2 and RMSE indicate that the inversion models based on the ratio spectrum and NSGA-III-ELM algorithm performed well in accurately predicting the N deficiency in rice.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the study on the quantitative description of the degree of nitrogen deficiency in rice using remotely-sensed UAV hyperspectral images?
Output:
In the study, three machine learning models were used to describe the degree of nitrogen deficiency in rice using remotely-sensed UAV hyperspectral images. These models are:

1) Multivariate Linear Regression (MLR): This model uses multiple input variables (characteristic bands) to predict the output variable (nitrogen deficiency).

2) Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) inversion model based on Extreme Learning Machine (ELM): This model combines LSTM, a type of recurrent neural network, with ELM, a type of feedforward neural network, to predict nitrogen deficiency.

3) Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III Extreme Learning Machine (NSGA-III-ELM): This model combines NSGA-III, a multi-objective optimization algorithm, with ELM to predict nitrogen deficiency.

instruction: Can the developed inversion model based on ratio spectrum and NSGA-III-ELM algorithm be considered superior to traditional methods for accurately determining nitrogen deficiency in rice using remotely-sensed UAV hyperspectral images?
Output: Yes, the developed inversion model based on the ratio spectrum and NSGA-III-ELM algorithm can be considered superior to traditional methods for accurately determining nitrogen deficiency in rice using remotely-sensed UAV hyperspectral images. The results showed that the inversion accuracy of the ratio spectrum was better than the accuracy of the original spectrum or difference spectrum. Additionally, the inversion accuracy based on the NSGA-III-ELM algorithm was better than the accuracy of the MLR algorithm or the ELM algorithm. The R2 values of the training set and validation set were 0.852 and 0.810, and the root mean square error (RMSE) values were 0.291 and 0.308, respectively. This indicates that the developed inversion model provides critical technical support for accurate topdressing based on the nitrogen status in rice.
